title: 111_hr5698
content: PROTECTION OF EMPLOYEES FROM RETALIATION BY EMPLOYER FOR COOPERATING IN INVESTIGATIONS: The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 is amended to include a new section prohibiting retaliation against employees. The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 is amended to include a new section prohibiting retaliation against employees for various actions such as reporting violations, refusing to participate in noncompliance, providing information to Congress or relevant proceedings. The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 is amended to prohibit retaliation against employees for reporting violations, providing information to Congress, or participating in legal proceedings under the Act. Employees can bring discrimination claims against employers following procedures outlined in the Act. The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 prohibits retaliation against employees for reporting violations or participating in legal proceedings. Employees alleging discrimination by an employer can bring an action under specific rules and procedures within 90 days of receiving a final determination by the Secretary of Labor. The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 prohibits retaliation against employees for reporting violations or participating in legal proceedings. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act now includes a new section prohibiting retaliation. The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 and the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act prohibit retaliation against employees for reporting violations, participating in legal proceedings, or providing information relevant to the Acts. Employees protected under the Oil Pollution Act of 1990 and the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act can take action if they report noncompliance, testify in proceedings, or assist in carrying out the purposes of the Acts. They can bring discrimination allegations against employers and seek legal remedies under specific rules and procedures. Employees protected under the Oil Pollution Act of 1990 and the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act can bring discrimination allegations against employers and seek legal remedies under specific rules and procedures, including district court review within 90 days of a final determination by the Secretary of Labor.
